{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{good article}} {{Infobox animal | name = Barry | image = Barry dog.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = A drawing of Barry, preserved at the [[Natural History Museum of Bern]] prior to the modifications conducted in 1923. | birth_name = Barry der Menschenretter<ref name="fleischli17">[[#fleischli|Fleischli (2006)]]: p. 17</ref> | othername = The Saint of Saints<ref name="hustace7">[[#hustacewalker|Hustace Walker (2000)]]: p. 7</ref> | species = Dog | breed = Referred to as a Küherhund or [[Alpine Mastiff]]; later as a [[St. Bernard (dog)|St. Bernard]] | gender = Male | birth_date = 1800 | birth_place = [[Great St Bernard Hospice]], [[Pennine Alps]] | death_date = 1814 | death_place = [[Bern]], Switzerland | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | relativeage = | nationality = Swiss-Italian | occupation = [[Search and rescue dog]] | employer = [[Great St Bernard Hospice]] | role = | years_active = 1800–1812 | known = | tricks = | awards = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = | parents = | children = | weight = {{convert|40|-|45|kg|lb}} | height = Less than {{convert|64|cm|in}} | appearance = | namedafter = | website = }} '''Barry der Menschenretter''' (1800–1814), also known as '''Barry''', was a dog of a breed which was later called the [[St. Bernard (dog)|St. Bernard]] that worked as a [[Mountain dog|mountain]] [[search and rescue dog|rescue dog]] in Switzerland and Italy for the [[Great St Bernard Hospice]]. He predates the modern St. Bernard, and was lighter built than the modern breed. He has been described as the most famous St. Bernard, as he was credited with saving more than 40 lives during his lifetime, hence his byname {{lang|de|Menschen[[wikt:Retter#German|retter]]}} meaning "people rescuer" in German.
The legend surrounding him was that he was killed while attempting a rescue; however, this is untrue. Barry retired to [[Bern]], Switzerland and after his death his body was passed into the care of the [[Natural History Museum of Bern]]. His skin has been preserved through [[taxidermy]] although his skull was modified in 1923 to match the Saint Bernard of that time period. His story and name have been used in literary works, and a monument to him stands in the [[Cimetière des Chiens]] near Paris. At the hospice, one dog has always been named Barry in his honor; and since 2004, the Foundation Barry du Grand Saint Bernard has been set up to take over the responsibility for breeding dogs from the hospice.
==History== [[File:Grand St-Bernard.jpg|thumb|left|The Great St Bernard Hospice]] The first mention in the Great St Bernard Hospice archives of a dog was in 1707 which simply said "A dog was buried by us."<ref name="fleischli16">[[#fleischli|Fleischli (2006)]]: p. 16</ref> The dogs are thought to have been introduced to the monastery as watchdogs at some point between 1660 and 1670.<ref name="fleischli16"/> Old skulls from the collection of the Natural History Museum of Bern show that at least two types of dog lived at the hospice.<ref name="dogshospice">{{cite web|title=The Dogs from the Hospice|url=http://www.nmbe.ch/deutsch/531_5_1_5.html|work=Naturhisorishches Museum Der Burgergemeinde Bern|accessdate=20 September 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100909020744/http://www.nmbe.ch/deutsch/531_5_1_5.html <!--Added by H3llBot-->|archivedate=9 September 2010}}</ref> By 1800, the year that Barry was born, it was known that a special kind of dog was being used for rescue work in the pass.<ref name="fleischli16"/> This general variety of dog was known as a Küherhund, or cowherd's dog.<ref name=museum />
Measurements of his preserved body show that Barry was smaller than the modern Saint Bernard, weighing between {{convert|40|and|45|kg|lb}} whereas modern Bernards weigh between {{convert|80|and|130|kg|lb}}. His current mounted height is approximately {{convert|64|cm|in}}, but the living Barry would have been slightly smaller.<ref name="museum">{{cite web|title=The Legendary Barry at the Natural History Museum|url=http://www.nmbe.ch/deutsch/531_5_1_9.html|work=Naturhisorisches Museum Der Burgergemeinde Bern|accessdate=20 September 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100907194857/http://www.nmbe.ch/deutsch/531_5_1_9.html <!--Added by H3llBot-->|archivedate=7 September 2010}}</ref>
During Barry's career, he was credited with saving the lives of more than forty people,<ref>{{cite web|last=Blumberg|first=Jess|title=A Brief History of the St. Bernard Rescue Dog|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history-archaeology/st-bernard-200801.html|publisher=Smithstonian.org|accessdate=21 September 2010}}</ref> although this number has sometimes varied over the years.<ref name=dogbook /> Barry's most famous rescue was that of a young boy. He found the child asleep in a cavern of ice.<ref name="ladies"/> After warming up the boy's body sufficiently by licking him, he moved the boy about and onto his back and carried the child back to the hospice.<ref name="fleischli16"/> The child survived and was returned to his parents,<ref name="ladies"/> although other sources say that the boy's mother died in the avalanche that trapped the boy.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The St. Bernard Dog|journal=The Plough, the Loom, and the Anvil|date=July 1850|volume=3|issue=1|page=90|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PC1MAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA90&dq=barry+st+bernard&hl=en&ei=Le6XTMjjNs-o4Ab9p-2jBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFMQ6AEwCDg8#v=onepage&q=barry%20st%20bernard&f=false|accessdate=21 September 2010}}</ref> The [[Museum of Natural History of Bern]] disputes the legend, attributing it to Peter Scheitlin,<ref name="lifesaving">{{cite web|title=Their Rescue and Life-Saving Work|url=http://www-nmbe.unibe.ch/deutsch/531_5_1_7.html|work=Naturhisorisches Museum Der Burgergemeinde Bern|accessdate=26 September 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101017152652/http://www-nmbe.unibe.ch/deutsch/531_5_1_7.html <!--Added by H3llBot-->|archivedate=17 October 2010}}</ref> an [[Comparative psychology|animal psychologist]].<ref name="italian">{{cite web|title=Cane di San Bernardo: Barry I, the "saint" of the Great Saint Bernard|url=http://www.canedisanbernardo.org/engl/capitolo9-engl.html|work=Italian Saint Bernard Club|accessdate=26 September 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725134357/http://www.canedisanbernardo.org/engl/capitolo9-engl.html|archive-date=25 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
{{quote|text=The best of dogs, the best of animals is Barry. You used to leave the convent with a basket round your neck, into the storm, in the most insidious snow. Each and every day you examined the mountain searching for unfortunates buried under avalanches. You dug them out and brought them back to life by yourself and, when you couldn't, you rushed back to the convent signalling the monks for help. You resurrected people. Your tenderness was so easy to communicate, that the boy you dug out had no fear to let you bring him, holding on to your back, to the Hospice.|sign=Peter Scheitlin|source=''Complete Study on Animal Instinct''<ref name=italian />}}
===Death=== There is a plaque on a monument in the [[Cimetière des Chiens]] [[pet cemetery]] which states, "{{lang|fr|Il sauva la vie à 40 personnes. Il fut tué par le 41ème}}" ("Barry saved the lives of forty people, but died while attempting to save his forty-first").<ref name=hustace7 /> The story goes that news had come that a [[Military of Switzerland|Swiss soldier]] was lost in the mountains. Barry was searching for the soldier and had picked up the scent, some forty-eight hours old, and finally stopped before a large bank of ice. He dug until he reached the soldier, and then licked him as he was trained. The Swiss soldier awoke startled and mistook Barry for a [[wolf]] and fatally stabbed him with his [[bayonet]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wilkins|first=H.T.|title=Dog Heroes of the Valley of Death|journal=Popular Mechanics|date=December 1931|volume=56|issue=6|page=901|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0-IDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA898&dq=barry+st+bernard&hl=en&ei=9baXTPzSO4f44AbFr9iaBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD4Q6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=barry%20st%20bernard&f=false|accessdate=20 September 2010}}</ref> James Watson in his 1906 work ''The Dog Book'' attributed the rumour to fellow author Idstone, also known as Reverend [[Thomas Pearce (priest)|Thomas Pearce]].<ref name="dogbook">{{cite book|last=Watson|first=James|title=The Dog Book|year=1906|publisher=Doubleday, Page & Company|page=575|url=https://archive.org/stream/dogbookpopularhi02wats#page/n347/mode/2up}}</ref>
However, the legend of his death is untrue. After twelve years of service at the monastery, Barry was brought by a monk to Bern, Switzerland so that he could live out the rest of his life. He died at the age of 14.<ref name=hustace7 /> His body passed into the hands of the Natural History Museum of Bern.<ref name=museum /> A special exhibit was held in his honor at the museum to commemorate his 200th birthday in 2000.<ref name="Barry">{{cite web|url=http://www.nmbe.ch/deutsch/531_5_1_9.html |title=The Legendary Barry at the Natural History Museum |work=Natural History Museum of Bern |accessdate=20 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429175208/http://www.nmbe.ch/deutsch/531_5_1_9.html |archivedate=29 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="Barry exhibit">{{cite web|url=http://www.nmbe.ch/deutsch/221_5.html |title=Barry 200 years – a tribute to the nose |date=9 June 2000 – 25 February 2001 |publisher=Natural History Museum of the Civic Community of Berne |accessdate=20 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127144819/http://nmbe.ch/deutsch/221_5.html |archivedate=27 November 2010 }}</ref> <ref name="Nussbaumer">{{cite book |first1=Marc |last1=Nussbaumer |title=Barry of the Great St. Bernard |pages=92 and 77 illustrations CHF 24}}</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:Barry der Rettungshund.jpg|thumb|right|Barry's preserved body as currently on display at the [[Natural History Museum, Bern]]]] The Hospice has always maintained one St. Bernard named Barry in the original's honor.<ref name="hustace8">[[#hustacewalker|Hustace Walker (2000)]]: p. 8</ref> During Barry's lifetime, his breed did not have one specific name.<ref name="fleischli19"/> By 1820, six years after his death, Barry was specifically referred to as being an [[Alpine Mastiff]],<ref name="ladies">{{cite book|editor=Woodworth, Samuel|title=The Ladies' Literary Cabinet|year=1820|publisher=Samuel Huestis|page=205|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z7AQAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA205&dq=barry+st+bernard&hl=en&ei=QsiXTLW7DY3aOMG60YkJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFMQ6AEwCDgU#v=onepage&q=barry%20st%20bernard&f=false}}</ref> while there was also a breed called the [[Alpine Spaniel]] which was recorded around the same time period.<ref name="bio278">{{cite book |title=Biographical Sketches and Authentic Anecdotes of Dogs |last=Brown |first=Thomas |year=1829 |publisher=Simpkin & Marshall |isbn= |page=278 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cC6FoV8cND4C&pg=PA278&dq=alpine+spaniel#v=onepage&q=alpine%20spaniel&f=false |accessdate=20 September 2010}}</ref> The English called the breed "sacred dogs", while the [[Verband für das Deutsche Hundewesen|German Kynology]] proposed the name "Alpendog" in 1828. Following his death and up until 1860, the entire stock were called "Barry hounds" in the [[Canton of Bern]] after Barry himself. It was not until 1865 when the term "St. Bernard" was first used primarily for the breed.<ref name="fleischli19">[[#fleischli|Fleischli (2006)]]: p. 19</ref><ref name="fleischli20">[[#fleischli|Fleischli (2006)]]: p. 20</ref> Under this name, the St. Bernard has been recognised since 1880 by the Swiss Kennel Club.<ref name="gentle" /> [[File:Barry.jpg|thumb|left|Drawing of Barry with a small child.]] Barry is described as the most famous St. Bernard by the [[Natural History Museum of Bern]]. Following his death, his skin was preserved by a [[Taxidermy|taxidermist]] for the museum,<ref name="museum"/> while the rest of his body was buried.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Dog of the Convent of St. Bernard|journal=The Monthly Magazine|date=February 1821|volume=51|issue=1|page=8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PVIoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA8&dq=barry+st+bernard&hl=en&ei=GumXTO2WLJD84Ab_t73xAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFEQ6AEwCDge#v=onepage&q=barry%20st%20bernard&f=false|accessdate=20 September 2010}}</ref> He was originally given a humble and meek pose, as the taxidermist felt that this would serve as a reminder of servitude to future generations. In 1923, his body was refurbished by Georg Ruprecht, as his coat had become brittle and had broken into more than 20 pieces. During the restoration, his body was re-posed and his skull shape was modified to match the shape of the St. Bernard of that time, in a compromise between Ruprecht and the Museum's director. His original head shape was rather flat with a moderate stop, with the modification resulting in a larger head with a more pronounced stop. A [[barrel]] was added hanging from his [[Dog collar|collar]],<ref name=museum /> following the popularization of the myth of the monastery's dogs using these during the rescues, which was originally introduced by [[Edwin Henry Landseer|Edwin Landseer]]'s work ''Alpine Mastiffs Reanimating a Distressed Traveller''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lloyd|first=John|title=The Book of General Ignorance|year=2007|publisher=Harmony Books|isbn=978-0-307-39491-0|page=32}}</ref> The barrel was removed in 1978 by Professor Walter Huber, the director of the museum, although it has since been replaced.<ref name="bibmuseum">{{cite web|title=Bibliography|url=http://www-nmbe.unibe.ch/deutsch/531_5_1_10.html|work=Naturhisorisches Museum Der Burgergemeinde Bern|accessdate=26 September 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101017152918/http://www-nmbe.unibe.ch/deutsch/531_5_1_10.html <!--Added by H3llBot-->|archivedate=17 October 2010}}</ref> A monument to Barry is located opposite the entrance to the [[Cimetière des Chiens]] in Paris.<ref>{{cite web|title=Les locataires du cimetière|url=http://www.asnieres-sur-seine.fr/Tourisme-international/Patrimoine/Le-cimetiere-des-animaux|work=Asnieres-sur-Seine.fr|language=French|accessdate=21 September 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925214243/http://www.asnieres-sur-seine.fr/Tourisme-international/Patrimoine/Le-cimetiere-des-animaux|archivedate=25 September 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In literary works, Samuel Rogers' poem ''The Great Saint Bernard'' is sometimes referred to as ''Barry, The Great St. Bernard''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rogers|first=Samuel|title=The Poetical Works of Samuel Rogers|year=1875|publisher=George Bell and Sons|page=195|url=http://xtf.lib.virginia.edu/xtf/view?docId=chadwyck_ep/uvaGenText/tei/chep_3.1813.xml}}</ref><ref name="doginpoetry">{{cite book|last=Leonard|first=R.M.|title=The Dog in English Poetry|year=1893|publisher=D. Nutt|pages=25 & 26|url=https://archive.org/details/doginbritishpoet00leon}}</ref> [[Henry Bordeaux]] praised Barry's work in his 1911 novel ''La Neige sur les pas''.<ref name=italian /> [[Walt Disney Productions]] made a telemovie entitled ''Barry of the Great St. Bernard'' in 1977,<ref>{{cite web|title=Barry of the Great St. Bernard (1977) (TV)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0276803/|work=IMDB|accessdate=20 September 2010}}</ref> and Barry's story has been featured in children's books such as ''Barry: The Bravest Saint Bernard'' published by [[Random House|Random House Books for Young Readers]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Lynn|title=Barry: The Bravest Saint Bernard|year=2007|publisher=Random House Books for Young Readers|isbn=978-0-375-84439-3}}</ref>
Until September 2004, 18 dogs still belonged to the hospice at any one time. The Foundation Barry du Grand Saint Bernard was established to create kennels in [[Martigny]], a village further down the pass, to take over the breeding of St. Bernard puppies from the friars at the hospice. Around 20 puppies per year are born at the foundation. In 2009, the St. Bernard Dog Museum was opened at the Foundation in Martigny and – to commemorate the occasion – Barry's remains were lent from the museum in Bern.<ref>{{cite news|last=Maurer|first=Urs|title=Legendary St Bernard rescue dogs find a home|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/Legendary_St_Bernard_dogs_find_a_home.html?cid=5373762|accessdate=26 September 2010|newspaper=swissinfo.ch|date=9 April 2009}}</ref> Each summer, the foundation leads dogs up the pass when it is open to the hospice, mainly for tourists, with rescue efforts on the pass now conducted by [[helicopter]]s.<ref name="gentle">{{cite web|title=St Bernard – Gentle Giants|url=http://www.dogsmonthly.co.uk/breed-features/st-bernard-gentle-giants/|work=Dogs Monthly Magazine|accessdate=20 September 2010}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox News event |name=Bihar school meal poisoning incident |image=India Bihar locator map.svg |caption=Location of Bihar in India |place=[[Mashrakh]], [[Bihar]]
{{IND}} |date={{start date|2013|7|16}} |cause=[[Food poisoning]] and yellow phosphorus poisoning |casualties1=25-27 |reported deaths=23 |arrests= |suspects= |accused= |charges= |verdict= }} On 16 July 2013, at least 23 students died and dozens more fell ill at a primary school in the village of Dharmashati Gandaman in the [[Saran district]] of the [[India|Indian]] state of [[Bihar]] after eating a [[Midday Meal Scheme|Midday Meal]] contaminated with pesticide. Angered by the deaths and illnesses, villagers took to the streets in many parts of the district in violent protest. Subsequently, the Bihar government took a series of steps to prevent any recurrence of such incidents. == Background == Across India, the [[Midday Meal Scheme]] provides roughly 120 million children with free lunch, making it the world's largest school lunch program.{{Cite news|date=17 July 2013|first=Soutik|last=Biswas|title=Why India's school meal deaths are a terrible tragedy|work=[[BBC News]]|location=London|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-23339206|accessdate=17 July 2013}} In spite of corruption involved in implementing the scheme, it aims to fight widespread poverty and improve children's school attendance and health as a large number of India's children suffer from malnutrition.{{Cite news|title=Corruption, poor quality taint India school meal scheme |date=19 July 2013|first1=Sunrita|last1=Sen|first2=Doreen|last2=Fiedler |work=[[Business Recorder]] |location=Karachi|url=http://www.brecorder.com/articles-a-letters/187/1212787/|accessdate=19 July 2013}} Bihar in northern India is among the nation's poorest states. According to [[Mashrakh]] residents, students have suffered from food poisoning after eating school lunches on multiple occasions. P. K. Shahi, [[Bihar]]'s education minister, said complaints about food quality were not uncommon but there had been no reported incidents of widespread food poisoning during his tenure. The nonprofit [[Hare Krishna Food for Life|Iskcon Food Relief Foundation]] describes the meal programmes in Bihar and neighbouring [[Uttar Pradesh]] as "the worst in India." Public health is poor in general, with most water sources contaminated, and hospitals underfunded. The primary school in the village of Dharmashati Gandaman was established in 2010. At the time of the incident, 89 children were registered with the school.{{cite news|title=Nine children die after mid-day meal in Bihar school|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/nine-children-die-after-midday-meal-in-bihar-school/article4921193.ece|work=[[The Hindu]]|location=Chennai|date=16 July 2013|accessdate=17 July 2013}} The food material for midday meals was stored at the house of the headmistress as the school did not have sufficient infrastructure. == Incident == On 16 July 2013, children aged between four and twelve years at the Dharmashati Gandaman primary school complained that their lunch, served as a part of the Midday Meal Scheme, tasted odd.{{cite news|title=Contaminated Lunches Kill 22 Children in India|first1=Gardiner|last1=Harris|first2=Hari|last2=Kumar|work=[[The New York Times]]|location=New York City|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/18/world/asia/children-die-from-tainted-lunches-at-indian-school.html|date=17 July 2013|accessdate=17 July 2013}} Children who questioned the food were rebuked by the headmistress. Earlier, headmistress Meena Kumari had been informed by the school's cook that the new cooking oil was discoloured and smelled odd. Kumari replied that the oil was purchased at a local grocery store and safe to use.{{cite news|title=Contaminated school meal kills 25 Indian children|work=[[Reuters]]|location=New York City|date=17 July 2013|first1=Annie|last=Banerji|first2=Mayank|last2=Bhardwaj|first3=Anurag|last3=Kotoky|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/17/us-india-chidren-poison-idUSBRE96G0AY20130717|accessdate=17 July 2013}} The cook, who was also hospitalized by the poisoning, later told reporters that it looked like there was "an accumulation of residual waste at the bottom [of the oil jar]". The meal cooked at the school that day consisted of soya beans, rice and potato curry. Thirty minutes after eating the meal the children complained of stomach pain and soon after were taken ill with [[vomiting]] and [[diarrhoea]]. The number of sick children overwhelmed the school and local medical system. Some of the sick children were sent home, forcing their parents to seek help on their own. According to the official count, 23 children died as a result of the contaminated food. Parents and local villagers said at least 27 had died. Sixteen children died on site, and four others were declared dead upon arrival at the local hospital. Others died in hospital. Among the dead were two children of a female cook, Panna Devi; her third child survived.{{cite news|title=Death toll rises to 22|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/death-toll-rises-to-22/article4924937.ece|work=[[The Hindu]]|location=Chennai|accessdate=17 July 2013|date=17 July 2013}}{{cite news|title=At least 23 more Indian children treated after getting sick at school lunch|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/19/world/asia/india-school-meal-poisoning|accessdate=20 July 2013|work=[[CNN]]|location=Atlanta|date=20 July 2013}} A total of 48 students fell ill from the contaminated food. Three remained in a critical condition as of 17 July. Thirty-one children were moved from the local hospital to [[Patna Medical College Hospital]] (PMCH) for further treatment. == Cause == Initial indications were that the food was contaminated by an [[organophosphate]], a class of chemicals commonly found in [[insecticide]]s.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/17/world/asia/india-school-meal-poisoning/index.html|title=School meals tainted with poison kill 22 children in Indian village|first1=Aloke|last1=Devichand|first2=Tim|last2=Hume|work=[[CNN]]|location=Atlanta|date=17 July 2013|accessdate=17 July 2013}} A local government administrator commented "It appears to be a case of poisoning but we will have to wait for forensic reports ... Had it been a case of natural food poisoning, so many children would not have died." Dr. Amar Kant Jha, superintendent of [[Patna Medical College and Hospital]] in [[Patna]], said that the survivors were emitting toxic vapours, which led his team to suspect almost immediately that they had been poisoned by an organophosphate.{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=204422677|title=Police hunt for principal after Indian school lunch deaths|last=McCarthy|first=Julie|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=2013-07-24}} Late on 17 July, officials stated that they believed the cooking oil had been placed in a container formerly used to store insecticides. According to state officials, the school’s headmistress had bought the cooking oil used in the food from a grocery store owned by her husband. On 20 July police said that a forensic report confirmed the cooking oil contained "very toxic" levels of [[monocrotophos]], an agricultural pesticide.{{cite news|title=India school lunch deaths: high pesticide levels found|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-23390972|work=[[BBC News]]|location=London|date=20 July 2013}}{{Cite news|title=India school lunch deaths: pesticide found|date=20 July 2013|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/20/india-school-meal-deaths-bihar-pesticide|accessdate=20 July 2013}} == Reactions == Nineteen of the children's bodies were buried on or near school grounds in protest. Across Bihar, numerous students refused to eat their meals in the days following the incident.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-23353017|title=India lunch deaths children buried in Bihar school|work=[[BBC News]]|location=London|date=18 July 2013|accessdate=18 July 2013}} On 17 July, hundreds of Mashrakh residents took to the streets in protest. Demonstrators lit fires and burned effigies of Bihar Chief Minister [[Nitish Kumar]]. Four police vehicles were damaged by the fires. Others threw stones at the police station and chanted slogans denouncing the government. Some villagers demanded that the Midday Meal program be scrapped.{{cite news | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Poison-theory-floats-as-Bihar-midday-meal-kills-27-kids/articleshow/21130119.cms | title=Poison theory floats as Bihar midday meal kills 27 kids | work=[[The Times of India]]|location=Mumbai | date=18 July 2013 | accessdate=18 July 2013}} Roads and rail lines were blocked by angry protesters carrying sticks and poles. Desks and chairs from the school were taken and smashed, while the kitchen area was destroyed. In nearby [[Chhapra]], multiple arson attacks were reported, including reports that a crowd set fire to a bus, but no injuries were reported from either city.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-23342003|title=Violent protests in India over school meal deaths|work=[[BBC News]]|location=London|date=17 July 2013|accessdate=17 July 2013}} Shahi commented that many people involved in the program are looking for easy money and that "it is just not possible to taste meals in all the 73,000 schools before children eat the food." He also alleged that the contaminated oil had been purchased from a member of a rival political party. Opposition party members accused the ruling [[Janata Dal (United)]] party of acting too slowly and called for a general strike. The Bihar government promised a thorough investigation and offered [[Indian rupee|INR]] 200,000 ([[United States dollar|US$]]3,400) compensation for families of the dead children. Kumar called an emergency meeting and dispatched forensic experts to Mashrakh. The headmistress and her husband fled after the deaths became public knowledge and she was suspended by the administrative authority. A [[First Information Report]] was filed against the headmistress for [[criminal negligence]], and police began searching for her. A district magistrate told the BBC that her property would be confiscated if she did not surrender to the authorities. She was apprehended by police in [[Chhapra]] on 24 July and held on suspicion of murder and criminal conspiracy.{{Cite news|title=Indian headteacher arrested after fatal school food poisoning: Meena Devi is arrested while travelling to court to hand herself in a week after tragedy left 23 children dead|first1=Jason|last1=Burke|first2=Manoj|last2=Chaurasia|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/24/indian-food-poisoning-school-headteacher-arrested|accessdate=19 July 2014|date=24 July 2013}}{{Cite news|title=India school poisonings: Principal arrested on murder charge|first=Mark|last=Magnier|date=24 July 2013|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|location=Los Angeles|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-india-school-food-poisoning-20130724,0,4520779.story|accessdate=24 July 2013}} In October 2013 the headmistress and her husband were charged with murder and faced the death penalty if convicted.{{Cite news|title=India school meal deaths: headteacher and husband charged with murder|date=22 October 2013|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/22/india-school-meal-deaths-headteacher-charged-murder|accessdate=19 July 2014}} ==Aftermath== [[Bihar Government]] has taken a number of steps to prevent the recurrence of such incidents. The Government issued a [[Toll-free telephone number|toll free number]] for all complaints related to Mid-Day Meal. It also ordered that the raw grain samples would be kept for three months at Godowns from where items for Midday Meal are supplied.{{cite web |title=Bihar Government to introduce Toll Free Number for Mid Day Meal |url=http://news.biharprabha.com/2013/09/bihar-government-to-introduce-toll-free-number-for-mid-day-meal/ |deadurl=no |accessdate=30 September 2013}} A case was filed by Akhilanand Mishra (one of the victims). On August 29, 2016, Meena Kumari was sentenced to 17 years in prison for her role in the incident. == Notes and references == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Disasters in India in 2013}} {{Portal bar|2010s|Bihar|Death|Disasters}} {{coord|25.3667|N|85.1333|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:2013 disasters in India]] [[Category:2013 health disasters]] [[Category:Academic meals]] [[Category:Death of children]] [[Category:Corruption in India]] [[Category:Deaths by poisoning]] [[Category:Disasters in Bihar]] [[Category:Disasters in schools]] [[Category:Health disasters in India]] [[Category:History of Bihar (1947–present)]] [[Category:Mass poisoning]] [[Category:Saran district]] [[Category:Schools in Bihar]] [[Category:Crime in Bihar]] [[Category:Food safety scandals]] [[Category:July 2013 events]]

{{BLP sources|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Bill Maris | image = Bill Maris Wiki.jpg | caption = Bill Maris 2016 | alma_mater = [[Middlebury College]] | known_for = Founder, [[Section 32]]
Founder, [[Google Ventures]] (GV)
VP of Special Projects at [[Google]]
Founder Burlee.com (now part of [[Web.com]])
Founder, [[Calico]]
}} '''Bill Maris''' is an entrepreneur and venture capitalist focused on technology and the life sciences. He is the founder and first CEO of [[GV (company)|Google Ventures (GV)]].{{cite web|title=Bill Maris|url=http://www.gv.com/team/bill-maris|publisher=gv.com|accessdate=7 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924024320/http://www.gv.com/team/bill-maris|archive-date=2015-09-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-03-09/google-ventures-bill-maris-investing-in-idea-of-living-to-500|title=Google Ventures and the Search for Immortality|date=2015-03-09|newspaper=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2016-10-23}} He is the creator of Google's [[Calico (company)|Calico]] project, a company focused on the genetic basis of aging.{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2013/10/09/the-brains-behind-calico-bill-maris-of-google-ventures/|title=The brains behind Calico? Bill Maris of Google Ventures|website=VentureBeat|access-date=2016-10-23}} He is the founder of early web hosting pioneer Burlee.com, now part of Web.com, and the founder of [[Section 32]], a California-based venture fund focused on frontier technology.{{Cite news|url=https://www.axios.com/google-ventures-founder-bill-maris-is-back-again-2314340835.html|title=Google Ventures founder Bill Maris is back. Again.|last=Primack|first=Dan|date=2017-03-14|work=Axios|access-date=2017-03-30|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://endpts.com/on-again-bill-maris-is-said-to-bankroll-a-100m-biotech-fund/|title=On again, ex-Google superstar Bill Maris is said to bankroll a $100M biotech fund|website=endpts.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-30}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.recode.net/2016/8/10/12434672/google-ventures-bill-maris-q-a|title=Google Ventures founder Bill Maris: ‘I’m leaving because everything is great.’|date=2016-08-10|website=Recode|access-date=2017-03-30}} == Education and early career == Maris graduated with a highest honors with a degree in neuroscience from Middlebury College.{{cn|date=March 2018}} Maris' background includes research at the [[Duke University Medical Center]] Department of Neurobiology. He has a degree in neuroscience from [[Middlebury College]].[https://charlierose.com/videos/17854 The Disruptive Ideas of Google Ventures] - Charlie Rose with Bill Maris and Kevin Rose, October 2012 (broadcast) Maris began his career as a biotechnology and healthcare portfolio manager for Swedish investment firm [[Investor AB]]. In 1997, Maris founded one of the first Web hosting companies, Burlee.com, and built the company's original computing, network and technological infrastructure after teaching himself to code from books purchased at the local Barnes & Noble. Burlee was subsequently acquired by Interland, Inc. and renamed [[Web.com]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.xconomy.com/san-francisco/2011/09/01/the-education-of-bill-maris-how-one-entrepreneurs-history-shaped-google-ventures/|title=The Education of Bill Maris: How One Entrepreneur's History Shaped Google Ventures {{!}} Xconomy|date=2011-09-01|newspaper=Xconomy|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-23}} Burlee.com was merged with Interland in 2002. Maris remained with the company until 2003. Interland subsequently changed its name to Web.com.{{Cite web|url=http://ir.web.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=268690|title=Interland Completes Acquisition of Web.com Assets: Assets Include Web.com Domain, Web Hosting Accounts, Registrar Business; Interland Announces Plans to Change Name to Web.com, Inc. (NASDAQ:WEB)|website=ir.web.com|access-date=2016-10-23}} Maris was a portfolio manager at Investor AB in 1997. It was on a business trip to Investor's headquarters in Stockholm where Maris was inspired to found Burlee.com after seeing a rack of servers in a closet which housed the company's email and web site.{{cn|date=March 2018}} == Career == In the mid 2000s, Maris partnered with entrepreneur [[David Green (social entrepreneur)|David Green]] to transfer a novel hydrophobic acrylic lens to Aurolab to cure cataract blindness in the developing world, where it has been used in more than 30 million patients.{{Cite web|url=http://www.schwabfound.org/content/david-green|title=David Green {{!}} Schwab Foundation for Social Entrepreneurship|website=www.schwabfound.org|access-date=2016-10-23}} Maris founded GV, formerly Google Ventures, in 2008 as the venture capital investment arm of [[Google Inc]]. He was responsible for the fund's strategy and management, and oversaw $3.0 billion in investments in technology and the life sciences.[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/24/technology/venture-capital-blends-more-data-crunching-into-choice-of-targets.html?pagewanted=all Google Ventures Stresses Science of Deal, Not Art of the Deal] - New York Times, June 2013 Maris was one of the first to cite the troubles with [[Theranos]], the troubled Silicon Valley blood testing company.{{cn|date=March 2018}} Maris founded [[Calico (company)|Calico]], a multibillion-dollar company whose mission is to understand and influence the genetic basis of aging. Google funded the company after Maris pitched the board of directors.{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2013/10/09/new-details-on-googles-anti-aging-startup/|title=New details on Google's anti-aging startup|date=2013-10-09|website=Fortune|access-date=2016-10-23}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/9/19/4748594/understanding-calico-larry-page-google-ventures-and-the-quest-for|title=Understanding Calico: Larry Page, Google Ventures, and the quest for immortality|last=Popper|first=Ben|date=2013-09-19|website=The Verge|access-date=2016-10-23}}{{Cite web|url=https://plus.google.com/+LarryPage/posts/Lh8SKC6sED1|title=I'm excited to announce Calico, a new company that will focus on health and…|website=plus.google.com|access-date=2016-10-23}} In a 2015 interview, Maris stated that health care breakthroughs can significantly improve the quality and duration of human lifespan across the globe, and that he is looking to invest in promising biotechnology companies.{{cite news|last1=Brooker|first1=Katrina|title=Google Ventures and the Search for Immortality|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-03-09/google-ventures-bill-maris-investing-in-idea-of-living-to-500|accessdate=9 April 2015|date=8 March 2015}} Maris was also the Vice President of Special Projects at Google, where he was heavily involved in [[X (company)|Google X]], [[Verily Life Sciences|Verily]].{{cn|date=March 2018}} Maris left Google Ventures on August 12, 2016, declaring "mission accomplished." {{Cite web|url=http://www.recode.net/2016/8/10/12434672/google-ventures-bill-maris-q-a|title=Google Ventures founder Bill Maris: 'I'm leaving because everything is great.'|last=Bergen|first=Mark|date=2016-08-11|website=Recode|access-date=2016-10-23}} In 2017 Maris founded [[Section 32]], a California-based venture fund with approximately $400 million under management.{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/16/bill-maris-has-closed-his-new-fund-with-150-million-to-accommodate-strong-investor-interest/|title=Bill Maris has closed his new fund with $150 million, to accommodate "strong" investor interest|last=Loizos|first=Connie|website=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-05-16}} == Personal life == In 2014, Maris married singer/songwriter [[Tristan Prettyman]] at [[Kruger National Park]] in South Africa. Their son Kylo Evergreen Maris was born on August 26, 2015.[https://instagram.com/p/63Qsz2k-1h/?taken-by=tristanprettyman Tristan Prettyman - Instagram] He filed divorce from Prettyman on April 20, 2018.[http://courtindex.sdcourt.ca.gov/CISPublic/casedetail?casenum=18FL004718N&casesite=NC&applcode=D] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == *{{Charlie Rose view|7546}} {{Alphabet Inc.}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maris, Bill}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American computer businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople in information technology]] [[Category:Google employees]] [[Category:Private equity and venture capital investors]] [[Category:Alphabet Inc. people]] [[Category:Life extensionists]]

[[File:Two u-CAT robots standing still.jpg|thumb|Two u-CAT robots that are being developed at the [[Tallinn University of Technology]] to reduce the cost of underwater archaeological operations]] '''Bio-inspired robotic locomotion''' is a fairly new subcategory of bio-inspired design. It is about learning concepts from nature and applying them to the design of real-world engineered systems. More specifically, this field is about making robots that are inspired by [[Biology|biological]] systems. [[Biomimicry]] and bio-inspired design are sometimes confused. Biomimicry is copying the nature while bio-inspired design is learning from nature and making a mechanism that is simpler and more effective than the system observed in nature. Biomimicry has led to the development of a different branch of robotics called [[soft robotics]]. The biological systems have been optimized for specific tasks according to their habitat. However, they are multifunctional and are not designed for only one specific functionality. Bio-inspired robotics is about studying biological systems, and look for the mechanisms that may solve a problem in the engineering field. The designer should then try to simplify and enhance that mechanism for the specific task of interest. Bio-inspired [[roboticists]] are usually interested in biosensors (e.g. [[eye]]), bioactuators (e.g. [[muscle]]), or biomaterials (e.g. [[spider silk]]). Most of the robots have some type of locomotion system. Thus, in this article different modes of [[animal locomotion]] and few examples of the corresponding bio-inspired robots are introduced.
[[Image:Stickybot.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Stickybot: a gecko-inspired robot]]
==Biolocomotion== Biolocomotion or animal locomotion is usually categorized as below:
===Locomotion on a surface=== Locomotion on a surface may include [[terrestrial locomotion]] and [[arboreal locomotion]]. We will specifically discuss about [[terrestrial locomotion]] in detail in the next section.
[[Image:Big-eared-townsend-fledermaus.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Big eared townsend bat (''Corynorhinus townsendii'')]]
===Locomotion in a fluid=== Locomotion in a blood stream [[heart failure|swimming]] and [[flying and gliding animals|flying]]. There are many [[Aquatic locomotion|swimming]] and [[flying and gliding animals|flying]] robots designed and built by roboticists.<ref name="flyingbot">R. Fearing, S. Avadhanula, D. Campolo, M. Sitti, J. Jan, and R. Wood, "A micromechanical flying insect thorax," Neurotechnology for Biomimetic Robots, pp. 469–480, 2002.</ref><ref name="swimmingbot">G. Dudek, M. Jenkin, C. Prahacs, A. Hogue, J. Sattar, P. Giguere, A. German, H. Liu, S. Saun- derson, A. Ripsman, et al., "A visually guided swimming robot," in IEEE/RSJ International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems, IROS, pp. 3604–3609, 2005.</ref><ref name="swimmingbot2">A. Alessi, A. Sudano, D. Accoto, E. Guglielmelli, "Development of an autonomous robotic fish," In Biomedical Robotics and Biomechatronics (BioRob), 2012 4th IEEE RAS & EMBS International Conference on (pp. 1032-1037). IEEE.</ref>
==Behavioral classification (terrestrial locomotion)== There are many animal and insects moving on land with or without legs. We will discuss legged and limbless locomotion in this section as well as climbing and jumping. Anchoring the feet is fundamental to locomotion on land. The ability to increase traction is important for slip-free motion on surfaces such as smooth rock faces and ice, and is especially critical for moving uphill. Numerous biological mechanisms exist for providing purchase: claws rely upon friction-based mechanisms; gecko feet upon van der walls forces; and some insect feet upon fluid-mediated adhesive forces.<ref name="animal locomotion">R. M. Alexander, Principles of animal locomotion. Princeton University Press, 2003</ref>
[[Image:Rhex.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Rhex: a Reliable Hexapedal Robot]]
===Legged locomotion=== Legged robots may have one,<ref name="hoppingrobot">M. H. Raibert, H. B. Brown, "Experiments in balance with a 2D one-legged hopping machine," ASME Journal of Dynamic Systems, Measurement, and Control, pp75-81, 1984.</ref><ref name="1leg">M. Ahmadi and M. Buehler, "Stable control of a simulated one-legged running robot with hip and leg compliance," IEEE Transactions on Robotics and Automation, vol. 13, no. 1, pp. 96– 104, 1997.</ref><ref name="1leg_2">P. Gregorio, M. Ahmadi, and M. Buehler, "Design, control, and energetics of an electrically actuated legged robot," IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics, Part B: Cybernetics, vol. 27, no. 4, pp. 626–634, 1997.</ref> two,<ref name="2leg">R. Niiyama, A. Nagakubo, and Y. Kuniyoshi, "Mowgli: A bipedal jumping and landing robot with an artificial musculoskeletal system," in IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation, pp. 2546–2551, 2007.</ref> four,<ref name="4leg">M. Raibert, K. Blankespoor, G. Nelson, R. Playter, et al., "Bigdog, the rough-terrain quadruped robot," in Proceedings of the 17th World Congress, pp. 10823–10825, 2008.</ref> six,<ref name="Rhex"/><ref name="isprawl1"/><ref name="isprawl2"/> or many legs<ref name="manyleg">S. Wakimoto, K. Suzumori, T. Kanda, et al., "A bio-mimetic amphibious soft cord robot," Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Part C, vol. 18, no. 2, pp. 471–477, 2006.</ref> depending on the application. One of the main advantages of using legs instead of wheels is moving on uneven environment more effectively. [[Bipedalism|Bipedal]], [[Quadrupedalism|quadrupedal]], and hexapedal locomotion are among the most favorite types of legged locomotion in the field of bio-inspired robotics. [[Rhex]], a Reliable Hexapedal robot<ref name="Rhex">U. Saranli, M. Buehler, and D. Koditschek, "Rhex: A simple and highly mobile hexapod robot," The International Journal of Robotics Research, vol. 20, no. 7, pp. 616–631, 2001.</ref> and Cheetah<ref name="Cheetah">Y. Li, B. Li, J. Ruan, and X. Rong, "Research of mammal bionic quadruped robots: A review," in Robotics, IEEE Conference on Automation and Mechatronics, pp. 166–171, 2011.</ref> are the two fastest running robots so far. iSprawl is another hexapedal robot inspired by [[cockroach]] locomotion that has been developed at Stanford University.<ref name="isprawl1">J. Clark, J. Cham, S. Bailey, E. Froehlich, P. Nahata, M. Cutkosky, et al., "Biomimetic design and fabrication of a hexapedal running robot," in Robotics and Automation, 2001. Proceedings 2001 ICRA. IEEE International Conference on, vol. 4, pp. 3643–3649, 2001.</ref> This robot can run up to 15 body length per second and can achieve speeds of up to 2.3 m/s. The original version of this robot was pneumatically driven while the new generation uses a single electric motor for locomotion.<ref name="isprawl2">S. Kim, J. Clark, and M. Cutkosky, "isprawl: Design and tuning for high-speed autonomous open-loop running," The International Journal of Robotics Research, vol. 25, no. 9, pp. 903– 912, 2006.</ref>
===Limbless locomotion=== Terrain involving topography over a range of length scales can be challenging for most organisms and biomimetic robots. Such terrain are easily passed over by limbless organisms such as snakes. Several animals and insects including [[worm]]s, [[snail]]s, [[caterpillar]]s, and [[snake]]s are capable of limbless locomotion. A review of snake-like robots is presented by Hirose et al.<ref name="snakebook">S. Hirose, P. Cave, and C. Goulden, Biologically inspired robots: snake- like locomotors and manipulators, vol. 64. Oxford University Press Oxford, UK, 1993</ref> These robots can be categorized as robots with passive or active wheels, robots with active treads, and undulating robots using vertical waves or linear expansions. Most snake-like robots use wheels, which are high in friction when moving side to side but low in friction when rolling forward (and can be prevented from rolling backward). The majority of snake-like robots use either [[Undulatory locomotion|lateral undulation]] or [[rectilinear locomotion]] and have difficulty climbing vertically. Choset has recently developed a modular robot that can mimic several snake gaits, but it cannot perform [[Concertina movement|concertina motion]].<ref name="snakebot1">R. Hatton and H. Choset, "Generating gaits for snake robots: annealed chain fitting and keyframe wave extraction," Autonomous Robots, vol. 28, no. 3, pp. 271–281, 2010.</ref> Researchers at Georgia Tech have recently developed two snake-like robots called Scalybot. The focus of these robots is on the role of snake ventral scales on adjusting the frictional properties in different directions. These robots can actively control their scales to modify their frictional properties and move on a variety of surfaces efficiently.<ref name="scalybot">H. Marvi, G. Meyers, G. Russell, D. Hu, "Scalybot: a Snake-inspired Robot with Active Frictional Anisotropy," ASME Dynamic Systems and Control Conference, Arlington, VA, 2011.</ref> Researchers at CMU have developed both scaled<ref>[https://www.wired.com/story/snakelike-skin-gives-a-robot-the-power-to-crawl/ SNAKELIKE SKIN GIVES A ROBOT THE POWER TO CRAWL]</ref> and conventional actuated snake-like robots.<ref>[https://www.wired.com/story/this-robot-snake-means-you-no-harm-really/ THIS ROBOT SNAKE MEANS YOU NO HARM, REALLY]</ref> {{further|Snakebot}}
===Climbing=== Climbing is an especially difficult task because mistakes made by the climber may cause the climber to lose its grip and fall. Most robots have been built around a single functionality observed in their biological counterparts. Geckobots<ref name="geckobot">O. Unver, A. Uneri, A. Aydemir, and M. Sitti, "Geckobot: a gecko inspired climbing robot using elastomer adhesives," in International Conference on Robotics and Automation, pp. 2329–2335, 2006.</ref> typically use van der waals forces that work only on smooth surfaces. Stickybots,<ref name="stickybot1">S. Kim, M. Spenko, S. Trujillo, B. Heyneman, D. Santos, and M. Cutkosky, "Smooth vertical surface climbing with directional adhesion," IEEE Transactions on Robotics, vol. 24, no. 1, pp. 65–74, 2008.</ref><ref name="stickybot2">S. Kim, M. Spenko, S. Trujillo, B. Heyneman, V. Mattoli, and M. Cutkosky, "Whole body adhesion: hierarchical, directional and distributed control of adhesive forces for a climbing robot," in IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation, pp. 1268–1273, 2007.</ref><ref name="stickybot3">D. Santos, B. Heyneman, S. Kim, N. Esparza, and M. Cutkosky, "Gecko-inspired climbing behaviors on vertical and overhanging surfaces," in IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation, pp. 1125–1131, 2008.</ref><ref name="stickybot4">A. Asbeck, S. Dastoor, A. Parness, L. Fullerton, N. Esparza, D. Soto, B. Heyneman, and M. Cutkosky, "Climbing rough vertical surfaces with hierarchical directional adhesion," in IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation, pp. 2675–2680, 2009.</ref> and<ref name="climbing_gait">S. Trujillo, B. Heyneman, and M. Cutkosky, "Constrained convergent gait regulation for a climbing robot," in IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation, pp. 5243–5249, 2010.</ref> use directional dry adhesives that works best on smooth surfaces. Spinybot<ref name="spinybot">A. Asbeck, S. Kim, M. Cutkosky, W. Provancher, M. Lanzetta, "Scaling hard vertical surfaces with compliant microspine arrays," The International Journal of Robotics Research, Vol.25, No. 12, pp. 1165-1179, 2006.</ref> and the RiSE<ref name="rise">M. Spenko, G. Haynes, J. Saunders, M. Cutkosky, A. Rizzi, D. Koditschek, et al., "Biologically inspired climbing with a hexapedal robot," Journal of Field Robotics, vol. 25, no. 4-5, pp. 223– 242, 2008.</ref> robot are among the insect-like robots that use spines instead. Legged climbing robots have several limitations. They cannot handle large obstacles since they are not flexible and they require a wide space for moving. They usually cannot climb both smooth and rough surfaces or handle vertical to horizontal transitions as well.
===Jumping=== One of the tasks commonly performed by a variety of living organisms is [[jumping]]. [[Bharal]], [[hares]], [[kangaroo]], [[grasshopper]], [[flea]], and [[locust]] are among the best jumping animals. A miniature 7g jumping robot inspired by [[locust]] has been developed at EPFL that can jump up to 138 cm.<ref name="jumpingbot">M. Kovac, M. Fuchs, A. Guignard, J. Zufferey, and D. Floreano, "A miniature 7g jumping robot," in IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation, pp. 373–378, 2008.</ref> The jump event is induced by releasing the tension of a spring. The highest jumping miniature robot is inspired by the locust, weighs 23 grams with its highest jump to 365 cm is "TAUB" (Tel-Aviv University and Braude College of engineering).<ref name="TAUB">V. Zaitsev, O. Gvirsman, U. Ben Hanan, A. Weiss, A. Ayali and G. Kosa, "A locust-inspired miniature jumping robot," in Bioinspiration & biomimetics, 10(6), p.066012.</ref> It uses torsion springs as energy storage and includes a wire and latch mechanism to compress and release the springs. ETH Zurich has reported a soft jumping robot based on the combustion of [[methane]] and [[laughing gas]].<ref name="combustion-driven soft robot">M. Loepfe, C.M. Schumacher, U.B. Lustenberger, and W.J. Stark, "An Untethered, Jumping Roly-Poly Soft Robot Driven by Combustion," Soft Robotics, Vol. 2, No. 1, pp. 33-41, 2015.</ref> The thermal gas expansion inside the soft combustion chamber drastically increases the chamber volume. This causes the 2 kg robot to jump up to 20 cm. The soft robot inspired by a [[roly-poly toy]] then reorientates itself into an upright position after landing.
==Behavioral classification (aquatic locomotion)==
=== Swimming (piscine) === It is calculated that when swimming some fish can achieve a [[Marine propulsion|propulsive]] efficiency greater than 90%.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.ece.eps.hw.ac.uk/Research/oceans/people/Michael_Sfakiotakis/IEEEJOE_99.pdf|author=Sfakiotakis|date=1999|title=Review of Fish Swimming Modes for Aquatic Locomotion|publisher=IEEE Journal of Oceanic Engineering|accessdate=2007-10-24|format=PDF |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070926175113/http://www.ece.eps.hw.ac.uk/Research/oceans/people/Michael_Sfakiotakis/IEEEJOE_99.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-26|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Furthermore, they can accelerate and maneuver far better than any man-made boat or submarine, and produce less noise and water disturbance. Therefore, many researchers studying underwater robots would like to copy this type of locomotion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rjmason.com/ramblings/robotFishMarket.html|author=Richard Mason|title=What is the market for robot fish?|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090704021443/http://rjmason.com/ramblings/robotFishMarket.html|archivedate=2009-07-04|df=}}</ref> Notable examples are the [[University of Essex|Essex University Computer Science]] Robotic Fish G9,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cswww.essex.ac.uk/staff/hhu/HCR-Group.html#Entertainment|publisher=Human Centred Robotics Group at Essex University|title=Robotic fish powered by Gumstix PC and PIC|accessdate=2007-10-25}}</ref> and the Robot Tuna built by the Institute of Field Robotics, to analyze and mathematically model [[Fish locomotion|thunniform motion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fibo.kmutt.ac.th/project/eng/current_research/fish.html|publisher=Institute of Field Robotics|title=Fish Robot|author=Witoon Juwarahawong|accessdate=2007-10-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071104081550/http://fibo.kmutt.ac.th/project/eng/current_research/fish.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-11-04}}</ref> The Aqua Penguin,<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E8B4_fGopzw youtube.com]</ref> designed and built by Festo of Germany, copies the streamlined shape and propulsion by front "flippers" of [[penguin]]s. Festo have also built the Aqua Ray and Aqua Jelly, which emulate the locomotion of manta ray, and jellyfish, respectively.{{Clear}} [[File:ISplash Robotic Fish.jpg|thumb|Robotic Fish: ''iSplash''-II]] In 2014 ''iSplash''-II was developed by PhD student Richard James Clapham and Prof. Huosheng Hu at Essex University. It was the first robotic fish capable of outperforming real carangiform fish in terms of average maximum velocity (measured in body lengths/ second) and endurance, the duration that top speed is maintained.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.isplash-robotics.com/|title=High-Speed Robotic Fish {{!}} iSplash|website=isplash-robot|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-07}}</ref> This build attained swimming speeds of 11.6BL/s (i.e. 3.7 m/s).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cswww.essex.ac.uk/staff/hhu/Papers/IEEE-IROS-2014-1080-1086.pdf|publisher=Robotics Group at Essex University|title=iSplash-II: Realizing Fast Carangiform Swimming to Outperform a Real Fish|accessdate=2015-09-29}}</ref> The first build, ''iSplash''-I (2014) was the first robotic platform to apply a full-body length [[Fish locomotion|carangiform]] swimming motion which was found to increase swimming speed by 27% over the traditional approach of a posterior confined waveform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cswww.essex.ac.uk/staff/hhu/Papers/IEEE-ICRA-2014-322-327.pdf|publisher=Robotics Group at Essex University|title=iSplash-I: High Performance Swimming Motion of a Carangiform Robotic Fish with Full-Body Coordination|accessdate=2015-09-29}}</ref>
==Morphological classification==
===Modular=== [[Image:HONDA ASIMO.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Honda Asimo: A Humanoid robot]] The modular robots are typically capable of performing several tasks and are specifically useful for search and rescue or exploratory missions. Some of the featured robots in this category include a [[salamander]] inspired robot developed at EPFL that can walk and swim,<ref name="salamander robot">A. J. Ijspeert, A. Crespi, D. Ryczko and J.-M. Cabelguen, "From swimming to walking with a salamander robot driven by a spinal cord model," Science, vol. 315, num. 5817, p. 1416-1420, 2007.</ref> a [[snake]] inspired robot developed at [[Carnegie-Mellon University]] that has four different modes of terrestrial locomotion,<ref name="snakebot1"/> and a [[cockroach]] inspired robot can run and climb on a variety of complex terrain.<ref name="Rhex"/>
===Humanoid=== Humanoid robots are robots that look human-like or are inspired by the human form. There are many different types of humanoid robots for applications such as personal assistance, reception, work at industries, or companionship. These type of robots are used for research purposes as well and were originally developed to build better orthosis and prosthesis for human beings. Petman is one of the first and most advanced humanoid robots developed at Boston Dynamics. Some of the humanoid robots such as Honda Asimo are over actuated.<ref name="hondahumanoid">K. Hirer, M. Hirose, Y. Haikawa, and T. Takenaka, "The development of honda humanoid robot," in IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation, vol. 2, pp. 1321–1326, 1998.</ref> On the other hand, there are some humanoid robots like the robot developed at Cornell University that do not have any actuators and walk passively descending a shallow slope.<ref name="passivewalking">S. Collins, M. Wisse, and A. Ruina, "A three-dimensional passive-dynamic walking robot with two legs and knees," The International Journal of Robotics Research, vol. 20, no. 7, pp. 607–615, 2001.</ref>
===Swarming=== [[Collective animal behavior|The collective behavior of animals]] has been of interest to researchers for several years. [[Ant]]s can make structures like rafts to survive on the rivers. [[Fish]] can sense their environment more effectively in large groups. [[Swarm robotics]] is a fairly new field and the goal is to make robots that can work together and transfer the data, make structures as a group, etc.<ref name="swarmrobotic">E. S ̧ahin, "Swarm robotics: From sources of inspiration to domains of application," Swarm Robotics, pp. 10–20, 2005.</ref>
===Soft=== [[Soft robotics|Soft robots]]<ref name="softroboticreview">Trivedi, D., Rahn, C. D., Kier, W. M., & Walker, I. D. (2008). Soft robotics: Biological inspiration, state of the art, and future research. Applied Bionics and Biomechanics, 5(3), 99-117.</ref> are robots composed entirely of soft materials and moved through pneumatic pressure, similar to an [[octopus]] or [[starfish]]. Such robots are flexible enough to move in very limited spaces (such as in the human body). The first multigait soft robots was developed in 2011<ref name="softrobotic">R. Shepherd, F. Ilievski, W. Choi, S. Morin, A. Stokes, A. Mazzeo, X. Chen, M. Wang, and G. Whitesides, "Multigait soft robot," Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, vol. 108, no. 51, pp. 20400–20403, 2011.</ref> and the first fully integrated, independent soft robot (with soft batteries and control systems) was developed in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web| title = Pneumatic Octopus is first soft, solo robot|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-37169109|publisher=BBC|accessdate=25 August 2016}}</ref>

[[Image:Biolex Logo.gif|thumb|right|200px|Logo]]
'''Biolex Therapeutics''' was a [[biotechnology]] firm in the [[Research Triangle Park|Research Triangle of North Carolina]] that was founded in 1997 and raised $190 million from investors. It filed for [[Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 7 bankruptcy]] on July 5, 2012.<ref> Chris Bagley, Staff Writer, for Triangle Business Journal. July 6, 2012. [http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/blog/2012/07/biolex-therapeutics-files-for-38m.html Biolex Therapeutics files for $38M bankruptcy]</ref>
The company focused on expression of difficult-to-synthesize recombinant proteins in its LEX platform, which used ''[[Lemna]]'', a [[duckweed]].<ref>Goodman Peter S. ''In N.C., A Second Industrial Revolution: Biotech Surge Shows Manufacturing Still Key to U.S. Economy [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/02/AR2007090201189.html]'' Washington Post Monday, September 3, 2007</ref> The duckweeds are a family of small aquatic plants that can be grown in sterile culture. Biolex developed [[recombinant DNA]] technology for efficiently producing [[pharmaceutical]] proteins in Lemna.<ref>John R. Gasdaska, David Spencer and Lynn Dickey "Advantages of Therapeutic Protein Production in the Aquatic Plant Lemna" BioProcessing Journal, Mar/Apr 2003.</ref> Therapeutic [[glycosylate]]d proteins, including [[monoclonal antibodies]]<ref>Cox KM et al. Glycan optimization of a human monoclonal antibody in the aquatic plant Lemna minor. Nat Biotechnol. 2006 Dec; 24(12): 1591-7.</ref> and [[interferon]] (IFN-alpha2b)<ref>De Leede LG, Humphries JE, Bechet AC, Van Hoogdalem EJ, Verrijk R, Spencer DG. Novel controlled-release Lemna-derived IFN-alpha2b (Locteron): pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and tolerability in a phase I clinical trial. J Interferon Cytokine Res. 2008 Feb; 28(2): 113-22.</ref> have been produced using the LEX platform.
Biolex acquired Epicyte Pharmaceutical Inc. on May 6, 2004, and acquired LemnaGene SA of Lyon, France in 2005.<ref>[http://www.lemnagene.com/communication/biolex_acquires_lemnagene_28_july_2005_for_immediate_release.pdf Biolex Therapeutics Acquires Lemnagene S.A.]</ref> Biolex was a privately held company, originally backed by Quaker BioVentures, The Trelys Funds, and [[Polaris Venture Partners]]. The term "[[plantibody]]" is trademarked by Biolex. In May 2012 Biolex announced that it sold the LEX System to [[Synthon (company)|Synthon]], a [[Netherlands]]-based specialty pharmaceutical company. The sale included two [[preclinical]] biologics made with the LEX System, BLX-301, a humanized and glyco-optimized anti-[[CD20]] antibody for [[Non-Hodgkin lymphoma|non-Hodgkin's B-cell lymphoma]] and other [[B-cell]] malignancies and BLX-155, a direct-acting [[thrombolytic]]. The financial terms of the sale were not disclosed.<ref>[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/biolex-sells-lex-system-synthon-130000231.html Biolex Sells LEX System to Synthon and Initiates Sale of Locteron(R)] Press Release: Biolex Therapeutics – Mon, May 7, 2012.</ref>

[[File:Gebärstuhl 19 Jh Volkskundemuseum Erfurt.jpg|thumb|upright|Birthing chair with foot placements]]
A '''birthing chair''', also known as a '''birth chair''', is a device that is shaped to assist a woman in the physiological upright posture during [[childbirth]]. It is intended to provide balance and support. If backless, it is known as a birth stool.
The early birthing chairs varied between having three or four legs, though three legged birthing chairs are most commonly seen.<ref name=Carson>Carson, Amanda. Birth Chairs, Midwives, and Medicine. Jackson, Mississippi: University Press of Mississippi, 1999.5. Print.</ref> Both styles support the bottom of the women in labor and often have a slender, sloped back for comfort and to allow [[Midwifery|birthing assistants]], who are positioned behind the mother in labor, to massage or support her. Often the arms of the chair have hand holds or arm rests for the mother to grip, providing extra leverage. Birthing chairs are usually 8 to 10 inches (20.32 centimeters- 25.4 centimeters) off the ground specifically to allow laboring women to brace their feet against the ground to help in pushing.<ref name=Carson/>
==History== {{See also|Obstetrics#History}}
[[File:Birthing Chair.jpg|thumb|upright|Birthing chair]] The birthing chair has been used for millennia. Birthing chairs took the place of laboring mothers sitting on birth attendant’s laps, as it was the previous practice. These chairs were used before male physicians dominated the delivery room.<ref>{{cite journal | pmc = 1449803 | pmid=12604487 | volume=93 | issue=3 | title=Early modern childbirth | year=2003 | journal=Am J Public Health | pages=432 |vauthors=Fee E, Brown TM, Beatty RL | doi=10.2105/ajph.93.3.432}}</ref> The use of the birthing chair or similar devices has been seen around the globe, not isolated to a particular region. The birthing chair can be traced to [[Egypt]] in the year 1450 B.C.E. Pictured on the walls of The Birth House at Luxor, Egypt, is an Egyptian queen giving birth on a stool. It can also be traced to [[Greece]] in 200 B.C as it is featured on an ancient Grecian sculpted votive.<ref name=Carson/>
[[File:Naissance en Alsace-Musée alsacien de Strasbourg (2).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Wooden birthing chair]] [[Celts|Celtic]] items from 100 B.C.E in Britain also depict women sitting in the same upright position as if in a birthing chair. Birthing chairs fell out of use after physicians began using the flat bed for women to lie on during delivery. A woman giving birth in the upright position has been seen in Asian, African, Pacific Islander, and Native American art. The concept of the birthing chair has also been written in observations by anthropologist as well as missionaries.<ref name=Carson/>
==In modern times== [[File:Romarad.jpg|thumb|Modern birthing chair]] As of the 1980s the birthing chair has been making a comeback in the modern medicine of childbirth. Some expecting mothers have reverted to the birthing chair for its upright position because it allows gravity to assist in the expulsion of the baby. Studies have shown that the birthing chair speeds up the time of delivery and increases comfort" for expecting mothers. The position of the birthing chair allows muscles(including vaginal and abdominal as well as those in the back, stomach, legs, and arms) used in [[childbirth]] to work to efficiency. Since the 1980s many hospitals have begun installing birthing chairs due to the large number of inquiries about them.<ref>Otten M.D, Carl . "Rebirth of the Birthing Chair." Saturday Evening Post. 254.1 (1982): 69. Web. 28 Feb. 2013. <http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=aph&AN=17928982&site=ehost-live></ref>
A modern birthing chair/stool can be made of many different materials including PVC inflatables such as the '''CUB support''', plastic such as the '''Kaya stool''' and '''padded wooden stools'''. More recently birthing chairs/stools have been made to accommodate several upright positions such as [[Squatting position|squatting]], [[All fours (human position)|all fours]], [[kneeling]] and [[sitting]], and are used as supports not necessarily as chairs or stools. Research suggests that '''being upright during labour''' can have many '''[[Childbirth positions|positive benefits for mother and baby]]'''.<ref>Child birth in squatting position Ayesha Nasir, K.J. Noorani, Razia Korejo Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre, Karachi. 2007</ref> Using a modern-day birthing chair/stool/support can aid a woman in having an upright birth.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lawrence A, Lewis L, Hofmeyr GJ, Dowswell T, Styles C | year = 2013 | title = Maternal positions and mobility during first stage labour | url = | journal = Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews | volume = 2 | issue = | page = CD003934 | doi = 10.1002/14651858.CD003934.pub2 }}</ref>

{{Infobox animal | name = Bobbie | image = Bobbie the Wonder Dog.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | othername = | species = Dog | breed = [[Scottish Collie]] | gender = Male | birth_date = 1921 | birth_place = | death_date = 1927 | death_place = | resting_place = [[Oregon Humane Society]] | nationality = American | occupation = | employer = | role = | years_active = | known = Traveling over 2,500 miles across the United States<ref group=upper-alpha>Based on odometer reading. Ripley's estimated he may have traveled as much as {{convert|2800|mi|km}}. {{cite web |url=http://www.silvertonbobbie.com/Home.html |title=Silverton Bobbie |accessdate=March 26, 2012}} </ref> | tricks = | awards = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = | parents = | children = | weight = | height = | appearance = | namedafter = | website = }} '''Bobbie the Wonder Dog''' (1921–1927) was a dog who covered {{convert|2551|mi}} on his own to return home to [[Silverton, Oregon]] after he was lost while his owners were visiting family in [[Wolcott, Indiana]].<ref name="Brazier">{{cite web |url= http://www.silvertonor.com/murals/bobbie/bobbie_wonder_dog2.htm |title= Bobbie - The Wonder Dog of Oregon |first= G. F. |last=Brazier |work= Animal Pals |editor= Wager-Smith, Curtis |year= 1924 |location= Philadelphia, Pennsylvania |publisher= Macrae Smith Company |at= City of Silverton, Oregon |accessdate= March 26, 2012}}</ref> [[Ripley's Believe It or Not!|Ripley's]] estimated the journey may have been as long as {{convert|3000|mi}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.silvertonbobbie.com/Photos.html#7 |title=Bobbie, the Prodigal Dog |format=photo array/cartoon |publisher=[[Ripley's Believe it or Not]] |accessdate=March 26, 2012}}</ref>
==Background== In August 1923, while on a family road trip in Indiana, Frank and Elizabeth Brazier, with their daughters Leona and Nova, were visiting relatives in [[Wolcott, Indiana]]. Their two-year-old [[Scotch Collie]]/[[English Shepherd]] mix dog Bobbie was attacked by three other dogs and ran away. After an exhaustive search, the heartbroken Brazier family were unable to find Bobbie and continued their trip before returning home to Oregon, expecting never to see their dog again.
==Journey home == In February 1924, six months later, Bobbie returned to Silverton mangy, dirty, and scrawny, with his toenails worn down to nothing. He showed all the signs of having walked the entire distance, including swimming rivers and crossing the Continental Divide during the coldest part of winter.<ref name=oe>{{Oregon Encyclopedia|bobbie_the_wonder_dog|Bobbie the Wonder Dog|author=Stelljes, Susan}}</ref>
During his ordeal, he crossed at least {{convert|2551|mi|km}} of plains, desert, and mountains in the winter to return home, an average of approximately {{convert|14|mi|km}} per day. After his return to Silverton, he experienced a meteoric rise to fame. His story drew national attention and was featured in numerous newspapers.<ref name = john/>
He was the subject of newspaper articles including ''[[Ripley's Believe It or Not!]]'', books, and film.<ref name=oe/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.silvertonbobbie.com/Photos.html#7 |title=Bobbie, the Prodigal Dog |format=photo array/cartoon |publisher=[[Ripley's Believe it or Not]] |accessdate=March 26, 2012}}</ref> Bobbie played himself in the 1924 [[silent film]] ''The Call of the West''.<ref name=oe/><ref>{{cite news |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19240711&id=bl0zAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TegDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1458,2064310 |title= Bobbie the Wonder Dog in ''The Call of the West'' |date= July 11, 1924 |work= [[The Register-Guard]] |accessdate= March 26, 2012}}</ref> He received hundreds of letters from people around the world and was honored with a jewel-studded harness and collar, ribbons, and [[key to the city|keys to cities]].<ref name=oe/>
People who had fed and sheltered Bobbie on his journey wrote the family to tell about their time with Bobbie. The Humane Society of Portland was able to use these stories to assemble a relatively precise description of the route Bobbie took.<ref name = john>John, Finn J.D. [http://offbeatoregon.com/o1101a-bobbie-the-wonder-dog-put-silverton-on-map.html “Wonder Dog’s” 2,500-mile odyssey put Silverton on the map] January 2, 2011 offbeatoregon.com</ref>
The humane society concluded that after returning to Wolcott and unable to find his owners, Bobbie initially followed their further travels into northeast Indiana. He then struck out in several directions, apparently seeking their scent. He eventually headed west.<ref name = john/>
During their original trip, the Braziers had parked their car in a service station each night. Their dog visited each of these stops on his journey, along with a number of homes, and a hobo camp.<ref name = john/>
In Portland, an Irish woman took care of him for a period of time when she found he had been injured, leaving his legs and paws gashed.<ref name = john/>
==Death and legacy== Upon his death in 1927, he was buried with honors at the [[Oregon Humane Society|Oregon Humane Society's]] [[pet cemetery]] in [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]]. A week later, German Shepherd film star [[Rin Tin Tin]] laid a wreath at his grave.<ref name="Brazier"/><ref name=oe/> His grave is sheltered by a "fancy white and red dog house" received during a promotional appearance at the Portland Home Show.<ref name="Brazier"/> The gravestone has been moved outside the house for better viewing.<ref name="roadside">{{cite web |url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/14881 |title=Grave of Bobbie the Wonder Dog Portland |publisher= Roadside America |accessdate= March 26, 2012}}</ref>
Bobbie's demonstration of loyalty is celebrated during Silverton's annual children's pet parade that serves as a reminder of the special place animals and pets have in people's lives. The event was started several years after Bobbie's death and the first parade was led by his son, Pal.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.sunset.com/travel/northwest/silverton-travel-00418000067498/ |title=Oregon Day Trip: Silverton |last=Hauser |first=Susan |journal=Sunset |date=May 2010 |accessdate=August 26, 2010}}</ref> A {{convert|70|ft|m|adj=mid|-long}} outdoor painting featuring Bobbie's story is part of a series of murals that decorate the walls of businesses in Silverton.<ref name=Walls>{{cite web |url= http://blog.oregonlive.com/terryrichard/2008/03/silverton.html |title= Silverton wears its history on its walls |last= Richard |first= Terry |date= March 21, 2008 |work= [[The Oregonian]] |accessdate= March 27, 2012}}</ref>
In late 2012, responding to public sentiment that his burial location in Portland did not properly honor his story and his connection to his hometown, a grassroots movement was started by a group of Silvertonians with the goal of repatriating Bobbie's remains to Silverton, for reburial and memorialization.<ref>[http://www.bringbobbiehome.com/ Bring Bobbie Home]</ref>

{{short description|American prostitute}} '''Dean Johnson''' (1961–2007) was a cross-dressing musician, party promoter, and was a highly recognisable figure in the downtown [[New York City]] [[nightlife]] in the 1980s, 1990s, and 2000s. Known for his towering height, shaved head, giant sunglasses, and penchant for wearing short cocktail dresses that exaggerated the length of his pale, lithe figure, Johnson played a seminal role in the emergence of the [[Queercore]] gay [[rock and roll]] subculture in the [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]].<ref name="NYT">{{Cite news|title=Disquieting Death Stills the Nite Life |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/14/fashion/14dean.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=2011-01-30 |first=Cara |last=Buckley |date=2007-10-14}}</ref>
==Music career == Both an underground rock star and a porn star, Dean Johnson fronted two bands: [[Dean and the Weenies]] and the [[Velvet Mafia]]. He partied with art-world luminaries like [[Keith Haring]], [[Jean-Michel Basquiat]], and [[Andy Warhol]], and performed at nightclubs such as; [[Area (nightclub)|Area]], [[Danceteria]], The Cat Club, and the [[Pyramid Club (New York)|Pyramid]].<ref name="NYT"/> Johnson was the driving force behind the ground-breaking “Rock and Roll Fag Bar” party, held Tuesday nights in the late 1980s at [[The World (nightclub)|The World]]. He subsequently produced the monthly “HomoCorps” live music showcase at [[CBGB]], which featured gay and transgender rock-and-roll bands.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Promoter and Queer Icon Dean Johnson Dies |url= http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2007/09/promoter_and_queer_icon_dean_j.html |work= New York Magazine |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref>
==Death == Johnson grappled with [[drug addiction]] and also was a [[sex worker]]. He died at age 46 from an apparent drug overdose while turning a trick in a Washington, D.C. apartment. There is some suspicion around his death, stemming from the fact that the man he was with had been found not guilty of murder in a trial held only a few weeks prior.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Dean Johnson’s E-Mails Shed New Light on His Strange Death|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2008-02-05/news/dean-johnson-s-e-mails-shed-new-light-on-his-strange-death/|work=The Village Voice|accessdate=2011-01-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170420130008/http://www.villagevoice.com/news/dean-johnsons-e-mails-shed-new-light-on-his-strange-death-6420463|archivedate=2017-04-20|df=}}</ref>

'''Fawzi al-Ghazzi''' (1891–1929) ({{lang-ar|فوزي الغزي}}), was a [[Demographics of Syria|Syrian]] politician known for being the father of the Syrian constitution. Ghazzi was born in [[Damascus]], he studied in Damascus and [[Istanbul]], and served in the Turkish army during [[World War I]]. After the [[Arab revolt]] he was appointed secretary of the Interior Ministry of the Arab Government in 1920. He was a staunch opposer to the [[French mandate of Syria|French mandate]], and was imprisoned several times and exiled, among other nationalist leaders, to the island of [[Arwad]]. He was elected as a Member of Parliament in 1928, and the chairman of the Constituent Assembly, which was responsible for writing the first Syrian Constitution, which was approved by the Parliament on July 4, 1928. He was poisoned by his wife for unknown reasons.
==References== [http://www.damascus-online.com/se/bio/ghazzi.htm Damascus Online]
